A game so good I continued playing it after Silksong

Enter the Gungeon is an absolute triumph of a game and a must-play for anyone who enjoys challenging, rewarding action. From the moment you pick it up, it’s clear that this is a game crafted with a profound love for its genre and a meticulous attention to detail.

The core gameplay loop is incredibly addictive. It's a top-down, bullet-hell rogue-lite that perfectly blends precise shooting mechanics with the thrill of randomized dungeon crawling. Each run feels fresh and exciting, thanks to the vast array of weapons and items you can discover. And "vast" is an understatement—the sheer creativity on display is staggering. You’ll find everything from a gun that shoots bees to one that fires t-shirts, all contributing to a uniquely chaotic and charming experience.

Dodge Roll, the developers, have infused the game with a personality that shines through every pixelated corner. The art style is gorgeous, the humor is spot-on (the "Gundead" enemies are a particular highlight), and the subtle references hidden throughout the Gungeon are a joy to uncover.

Yes, the game is difficult. It’s a bullet-hell, after all. You will die. A lot. But the beauty of Enter the Gungeon lies in its progression system. You constantly unlock new weapons, items, and characters, ensuring that every failure feels like a step toward a deeper understanding of the game’s mechanics. The learning curve is steep but incredibly satisfying to master. Executing a perfect dodge roll through a storm of bullets and clearing a room of enemies feels incredibly rewarding.

Ultimately, Enter the Gungeon is a masterclass in game design. It's challenging, charming, replayable, and a genuinely joyous experience. It's a game that respects your time and rewards your skill, making it an easy recommendation for anyone looking for a new obsession. Lock and load; you won't regret entering this Gungeon!
Best roguelike I've ever played. The gameplay is so slick I could probably play it forever.

The quintessential rogue-lite

That said a very sober take on the genre, where you don't end up with modifiers up the butt until you fill the room with bullets, [i]frequently[/i], instead most runs will prove a real challenge, one which I think always feels very fair.

Enter the Gungeon is a fantastic bullet hell indie game that's very well made, but make no mistake, this is a very challenging and difficult game.  That being said, anyone can get used to the game very easily, and you don't have to put lots of effort in learning all of the rules, tricks and quirks of the game (unlike some other roguelikes).  Don't be discouraged if you have never played a game from this genre before.

The game is simple: you are in a dungeon, where everything is against you (well, except for the friendly NPCs), and your task is to defeat them with any of the weapons you find during your journey.  One thing to keep in mind is that you'll lose many, many times (at the time of writing this review, after having played the game for a total of 72 hours, I have just recently completed a run).  Even then, I have always found myself wanting to play more, again and again.

Being lightweight, just about any computer made in the past 16 years should be able to handle it just fine, but this doesn't mean that the game's visuals are poor, in fact, the art, special effects and sound effects all look fantastic.  The soundtrack is fine, and the game has a great sense of humor.

This game is perfect for playing all by yourself, but it's even better if you have a friend to play cooperatively.

not bad, fun to zone out on. doesn't hurt too much when you die, but sadly it gets increasingly hard as you play because as you unlock items, you stop getting the "Good" ones as often, but i do belive you can narrow the item spawn to just what you like
genuinely quite a fun and underrated game, half the time down to luck though not unplayable without good luck or unlocking progression based items

The quintessential roguelike game that IMO defined the genre. Big guns, gun enemies and even bigger guns.

Really good, the closest game to Isaac that I have seen. Although it can feel boring and overtly hard at the beginning. If you are able to power through the first past killing, you'll prolly have whatever you need to make the rest of the runs really fun.
Its just one of them fun bullet hell games that are so hard you cant defeat the first boss... i recommend playing solo or with friends! both are fun!
Why can't I beat this stupid fucking game! Great mechanics though.

The game as a whole is fantastic and very fun and it only really has 2 issues.

1. the game expecting you to remember every single item function and combo is a bit absurd, you basically have to keep the wiki open as some combos can straight up sabotage you by doing things like dropping ice or oil/fire on the ground without giving you immunity. (this doesn't happen often and is therefore a rather minor issue but one i still wanted to mention)

2. the bullet hell is straight up bs. while the boss of the area is great, he is in my opinion, the hardest boss in the game and the fact that you have to do a run lasting 30+ mins just to get to practice on him is absurd, especially considering that most of the time due to how spammy the enemies in the bullet hell are and how many rooms there are on the floor you  will often end up getting to the boss with next to no hp left, meaning you prob won't get to practice on him too long before you end up having to restart and waste another 30+ minutes just getting to him (obv you can somewhat ignore this point if you are the type of person to just look up a guide on how to beat a boss, since that will give you enough knowledge to beat him 2nd tor 3rd try probably)

For some reason, every run of gungeon feels, ultimately, doable. I never really get upset at the game for losing.

Yes there are ways to break the game and make it trivial, but at the foreground of this game is a test of skill. How well you can adjust to the attack patterns, how to make best use of your weapons. Its' not as strategic as other rougelikes, but that missing aspect is made up for by how fun the base game mechanics are.

If you aren't accustomed to the genre, this is a great entry-point. It will fuck you up, but you will like it and go back for seconds.
No engine simulation to speak of but I think that since this game is about an entirely different topic its acceptable, ergo its still good nonetheless
This game will totally piss you off! However, super fun and very rewarding! Just need a lot of patience and a lot of focus!

Замечательный рогалик с кучей необычного оружия, разнообразными боссами и забавными режимами. При полном прохождении игра дает уйму испытаний разной сложности, которые позволяют пересмотреть стратегии прохождения и улучшить навыки. Не обошлось и без чудо-Фрайфла с его заданиями на износ, но за это время можно накопить денег, купить и попробовать намного больше оружия, чем без этого длительного испытания. Отдельно хочется выделить крысу, как самого интересного босса, начиная от получения доступа к ее этажу до опциональной последней стадии, которая является уникальной для всей игры.

I put in about 70 hours, and though sometimes I figured no way I can beat it… bam I go on an epic run.  Gameplay loop is excellent.

I have about 430 hours played on Xbox, this was mine and a friends couch co op of choice. I remember fighting myself to try to play anything else except Gungeon, because it was so good. We kept discovering secrets and combos, the hidden floors, and that damn crest, I still freak whenever I break a water barrel. Finally seeing the one gun and laughing out loud.  I still dont think I ever saw the entirety of the endgame. I know theres been a floor added since i've played as well. Me and a friend of mine recently had a game night and the first think I thought of was gungeon. Played a few runs and kept dying to the bullet twins and laughed every time. I love this game more than most I've ever played, and I really do find myself still chasing the high that this game first gave me. Of course you always move on and find the next one, nevertheless Gungeon holds a huge spot in my heart, and always will.

I'll throw in a recipe for Varenyky.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

negative.review:
This game is 100% style over substance. It's neither a good roguelite nor a good bullet hell, yet somehow the worst of both worlds combined. 

It's an completely unbalanced mess with extremely slow and tedious meta progression, no character building whatsoever and 99% of all items/guns are trash. The dodge roll mechanic goes against everything any real bullet hell shoot em up teaches you and does ultimately more harm than good. Bosses are ridiculous bullet sponges and mid bosses are even worse.

It does look nice, I give it that. But so does The Binding of Isaac and that game plays really well and is a lot of fun.

Go buy The Binding of Isaac.

Game misuses the "Bullet Hell" tag, as not only game's "dodging" focuses primarily on bullet cancels/dodge roll abusing/macrododging (macrododging - going around bullets), but also character hitboxes are too big, disrespecting the deep and dead subgenre that it's using as an aesthetic/marketing choice to appeal to mainsteam audience.

If anything, Enter the Gungeon is more of a cover shooter rather than an actual bullet hell.
Roguelike isn't my favorite genre, but some have hit for me. I found the gameplay of this one boring despite usually loving twin-stick shooters.
great game, love it with all my heart, the lost adventurer achievement can go blow its brains out in an alleyway.

The "bullet hell" half of this game is great. Amazing bosses, gunplay, cool guns.

But the "roguelike" sucks:
- Runs blend together.
- No time-limit means I'm incentivized to clear every room, which is boring.
- Replaying early chambers every run is boring as fuck. (you're incentivized to not skip)
- OP guns completely break the balance of certain runs. Makes wins feel undeserved.

I beat the normal ending on some characters but couldn't bother with anything else.
Wish I had bought hades instead.

I know it's part of the rougelike to have good and bad runs, strong and weak weapons, and easy and hard enemies, but it doesn't matter that "rougelikes are just like that" when the aim of a game is to be fun. No, I'm not saying Enter the Gungeon is not fun, it is overall pretty fun to me. But there are parts about this game that are very VERY not fun that I wish didn't effect my playing experience. Look, I know rouguelikes are inherently unfair at times, I know EtG is a rougelike, I know not every run is supposed to finish, but sometimes I end a run cursing the game itself more often than its enemies, and I don't think that's intended. 
Here's the thing, EtG is HARD. I know that, I know it's supposed to be, and I like the difficulty. My favorite bosses are the Treadnaught and the Kill Pillars. They are both VERY bullet hellish bosses, on par with the Lich and Dragon boss. What sets them apart from those others though, is their consistent, hard but fair difficulty. The tank boss will always shoot small bullets at you from behind, clamping you in with a main caliber round. Very hard to dodge, but I can see it from a mile away, and the columns in the boss room help as, though temporary, good cover. The lich also has this at parts, but the 3rd stage's lack of telegraphing of where the chain thingies go have sniped me out of a run more times than I'd like. The dragon has this spray attack that spits bullets fast enough that I can't weave through them, but slow enough that a dodge roll is ended with a stray bullet. 
This is my biggest grope with this game. Stray bullets, wiggly bullets, those offscreen guns during the high priest boss. They come out of nowhere. Now, I understand it's just the nature of a procedural generated game to have random elements and that these random elements will eventually end with a stray bullet ending a run or two, but wiggly bullets? offscreen bullets? Those were intentional and have caused me to say "WHY DO THOSE EXIST" and whatnot.
I will say this though, occasional vietkong or worm bullets is not bad design. In fact, I am a firm believer that impending damage can add a lot to a game, but in this game, the damage these bullets do is enormous in a given run. Only 1 stray bullet a floor will result in half health by Bullet Hell, that's not including general damage from bosses or enemies, and assuming two heart upgrades are found. Seriously, the chip damage the Gungeon will do kills more than the Lich. So what's the point then? What am I trying to get across now?

Let me be clear, Enter the Gungeon is a fun game overall, but I would not recommend this game for one simple reason: You don't control your health. I can accept wiggly bullets, I can accept a lead maiden in a room with no cover, but only in a game where I have a chance to heal up after such scenarios. In later floors, health is scarce, and you cant even use an Item to regain any health or convert your Gungeoneering skill to a health reward because health and armour related items are either super rare, or single use and super rare. Additionally, saved health doesn't travel across floors, which if it did, I would maybe think differently about this game.
Again, EtG is fun, but I can't recommend subjecting yourself to a slow hellish forthcoming burn. you know what, maybe that's the point. Maybe the Gungeon is SUPPOSED to be hell. Maybe that was the idea, to make the experience of crawling deeper and deeper and having every run ended with an unfair pitfall. But  this isn't hell, it's a game, and the aim of a game is to be fun.

Feels more like a shoot em up than a rouge like and im surprised this is as popular as it is. None of the characters or items feel really unique to me. The unlock system feels poor to me. Visuals also can get crazy in a rouge like bullet hell but sometimes it seems like poor design to me. Red bullets in a room with red carpet with red indicators for enemy spawns that can spawn red enemies. Speaking of visuals for how underwhelming most guns are they make a lot of visual clutter.

Floor two Bulletkin (veteran Shotgun kin...) were showing up on floor 1. Any fun I was having evaporated. Checked the wiki, and it's a feature. Cmon. The skill floor isn't even high, it's just entirely random based on whether or not the game likes you. Play another bullet hell that's cheaper and actually relies on skill to unlock secrets.

i dont like this game

I can’t quite see the appeal of this game. As a roguelike, its RNG design feels off. There’s a large pool of weapons, but in practice they barely differ beyond DPS. Meanwhile, the maps, enemy encounters, and bosses vary so little that runs feel like pre-designed stages rather than true roguelike experiences. Character building also feels shallow: you rarely get meaningful choices at chests or shops—most of the time you’re stuck with a simple take-it-or-leave-it decision.
Unfortunately I didn't like this game and I played for 30 hours trying to like it. I'm definitely the problem lol.

This game is 100% style over substance. It's neither a good roguelite nor a good bullet hell, yet somehow the worst of both worlds combined. 

It's an completely unbalanced mess with extremely slow and tedious meta progression, no character building whatsoever and 99% of all items/guns are trash. The dodge roll mechanic goes against everything any real bullet hell shoot em up teaches you and does ultimately more harm than good. Bosses are ridiculous bullet sponges and mid bosses are even worse.

It does look nice, I give it that. But so does The Binding of Isaac and that game plays really well and is a lot of fun.

Go buy The Binding of Isaac.

This might be my least favorite roguelike yet. It missed the mark so hard. 

It feels like they collected a big pile of assets and then put them into an RNG. 

They could have used these resources to actually make an awesome game.

To me, that's not really a 'game'. It feels really lazy. Like I'm just gambling with my time at their unfinished casino. 

The progression is very unrewarding. The entire challenge of the game feels like I'm suffering through the developers laziness instead of enjoying their vision.

The "bullet hell" half of this game is great. Amazing bosses, gunplay, cool guns.

But the "roguelike" sucks:
- Runs blend together.
- No time-limit means I'm incentivized to clear every room, which is boring.
- Replaying early chambers every run is boring as fuck. (you're incentivized to not skip)
- OP guns completely break the balance of certain runs. Makes wins feel undeserved.

I beat the normal ending on some characters but couldn't bother with anything else.
Wish I had bought hades instead.

Not a big fan of the pseudo ice skating esque movement. The game as a whole is beautiful, but the arcade version is more fun tbh.

In fact, I am a firm believer that impending damage can add a lot to a game, but in this game, the damage these bullets do is enormous in a given run. Only 1 stray bullet a floor will result in half health by Bullet Hell, that's not including general damage from bosses or enemies, and assuming two heart upgrades are found. Seriously, the chip damage the Gungeon will do kills more than the Lich. So what's the point then? What am I trying to get across now?

Let me be clear, Enter the Gungeon is a fun game overall, but I would not recommend this game for one simple reason: You don't control your health. I can accept wiggly bullets, I can accept a lead maiden in a room with no cover, but only in a game where I have a chance to heal up after such scenarios. In later floors, health is scarce, and you cant even use an Item to regain any health or convert your Gungeoneering skill to a health reward because health and armour related items are either super rare, or single use and super rare. Additionally, saved health doesn't travel across floors, which if it did, I would maybe think differently about this game.
Again, EtG is fun, but I can't recommend subjecting yourself to a slow hellish forthcoming burn. you know what, maybe that's the point. Maybe the Gungeon is SUPPOSED to be hell. Maybe that was the idea, to make the experience of crawling deeper and deeper and having every run ended with an unfair pitfall. But  this isn't hell, it's a game, and the aim of a game is to be fun.
great game, love it with all my heart, the lost adventurer achievement can go blow its brains out in an alleyway.

Game misuses the "Bullet Hell" tag, as not only game's "dodging" focuses primarily on bullet cancels/dodge roll abusing/macrododging (macrododging - going around bullets), but also character hitboxes are too big, disrespecting the deep and dead subgenre that it's using as an aesthetic/marketing choice to appeal to mainsteam audience.

If anything, Enter the Gungeon is more of a cover shooter rather than an actual bullet hell.

Feels more like a shoot em up than a rouge like and im surprised this is as popular as it is. None of the characters or items feel really unique to me. The unlock system feels poor to me. Visuals also can get crazy in a rouge like bullet hell but sometimes it seems like poor design to me. Red bullets in a room with red carpet with red indicators for enemy spawns that can spawn red enemies. Speaking of visuals for how underwhelming most guns are they make a lot of visual clutter.

Floor two Bulletkin (veteran Shotgun kin...) were showing up on floor 1. Any fun I was having evaporated. Checked the wiki, and it's a feature. Cmon. The skill floor isn't even high, it's just entirely random based on whether or not the game likes you. Play another bullet hell that's cheaper and actually relies on skill to unlock secrets.

this game sucks and everyone who ever tried to convince me that its good is evil
what if nuclear throne was really slow and felt terrible to play and had items that didnt do anything

Ridiculously hard. There's no sense of achievement or feeling of advancement. You have to try like 500 times to get a good run. There are many other bullet hell games that are much more fun and enjoyable than this. Don't recommend. Trust
getting 100% in this game is absolutely miserable
grindy and no meta progression. just not fun.
Felt too repetitive too fast.
i dont like this game

I can’t quite see the appeal of this game. As a roguelike, its RNG design feels off. There’s a large pool of weapons, but in practice they barely differ beyond DPS. Meanwhile, the maps, enemy encounters, and bosses vary so little that runs feel like pre-designed stages rather than true roguelike experiences. Character building also feels shallow: you rarely get meaningful choices at chests or shops—most of the time you’re stuck with a simple take-it-or-leave-it decision.

This game is 100% style over substance. It's neither a good roguelite nor a good bullet hell, yet somehow the worst of both worlds combined. 

It's an completely unbalanced mess with extremely slow and tedious meta progression, no character building whatsoever and 99% of all items/guns are trash. The dodge roll mechanic goes against everything any real bullet hell shoot em up teaches you and does ultimately more harm than good. Bosses are ridiculous bullet sponges and mid bosses are even worse.

It does look nice, I give it that. But so does The Binding of Isaac and that game plays really well and is a lot of fun.

Go buy The Binding of Isaac.

This might be my least favorite roguelike yet. It missed the mark so hard. 

It feels like they collected a big pile of assets and then put them into an RNG. 

They could have used these resources to actually make an awesome game.

To me, that's not really a 'game'. It feels really lazy. Like I'm just gambling with my time at their unfinished casino. 

The progression is very unrewarding. The entire challenge of the game feels like I'm suffering through the developers laziness instead of enjoying their vision.
Roguelike isn't my favorite genre, but some have hit for me. I found the gameplay of this one boring despite usually loving twin-stick shooters.
Not a big fan of the pseudo ice skating esque movement. The game as a whole is beautiful, but the arcade version is more fun tbh.
incredible game, but there are to much crashes

The "bullet hell" half of this game is great. Amazing bosses, gunplay, cool guns.

But the "roguelike" sucks:
- Runs blend together.
- No time-limit means I'm incentivized to clear every room, which is boring.
- Replaying early chambers every run is boring as fuck. (you're incentivized to not skip)
- OP guns completely break the balance of certain runs. Makes wins feel undeserved.

I beat the normal ending on some characters but couldn't bother with anything else.
Wish I had bought hades instead.

I know it's part of the rougelike to have good and bad runs, strong and weak weapons, and easy and hard enemies, but it doesn't matter that "rougelikes are just like that" when the aim of a game is to be fun. No, I'm not saying Enter the Gungeon is not fun, it is overall pretty fun to me. But there are parts about this game that are very VERY not fun that I wish didn't effect my playing experience. Look, I know rouguelikes are inherently unfair at times, I know EtG is a rougelike, I know not every run is supposed to finish, but sometimes I end a run cursing the game itself more often than its enemies, and I don't think that's intended. 
Here's the thing, EtG is HARD. I know that, I know it's supposed to be, and I like the difficulty. My favorite bosses are the Treadnaught and the Kill Pillars. They are both VERY bullet hellish bosses, on par with the Lich and Dragon boss. What sets them apart from those others though, is their consistent, hard but fair difficulty. The tank boss will always shoot small bullets at you from behind, clamping you in with a main caliber round. Very hard to dodge, but I can see it from a mile away, and the columns in the boss room help as, though temporary, good cover. The lich also has this at parts, but the 3rd stage's lack of telegraphing of where the chain thingies go have sniped me out of a run more times than I'd like. The dragon has this spray attack that spits bullets fast enough that I can't weave through them, but slow enough that a dodge roll is ended with a stray bullet. 
This is my biggest grope with this game. Stray bullets, wiggly bullets, those offscreen guns during the high priest boss. They come out of nowhere. Now, I understand it's just the nature of a procedural generated game to have random elements and that these random elements will eventually end with a stray bullet ending a run or two, but wiggly bullets? offscreen bullets? Those were intentional and have caused me to say "WHY DO THOSE EXIST" and whatnot.
I will say this though, occasional vietkong or worm bullets is not bad design. In fact, I am a firm believer that impending damage can add a lot to a game, but in this game, the damage these bullets do is enormous in a given run. Only 1 stray bullet a floor will result in half health by Bullet Hell, that's not including general damage from bosses or enemies, and assuming two heart upgrades are found. Seriously, the chip damage the Gungeon will do kills more than the Lich. So what's the point then? What am I trying to get across now?

Let me be clear, Enter the Gungeon is a fun game overall, but I would not recommend this game for one simple reason: You don't control your health. I can accept wiggly bullets, I can accept a lead maiden in a room with no cover, but only in a game where I have a chance to heal up after such scenarios. In later floors, health is scarce, and you cant even use an Item to regain any health or convert your Gungeoneering skill to a health reward because health and armour related items are either super rare, or single use and super rare. Additionally, saved health doesn't travel across floors, which if it did, I would maybe think differently about this game.
Again, EtG is fun, but I can't recommend subjecting yourself to a slow hellish forthcoming burn. you know what, maybe that's the point. Maybe the Gungeon is SUPPOSED to be hell. Maybe that was the idea, to make the experience of crawling deeper and deeper and having every run ended with an unfair pitfall. But  this isn't hell, it's a game, and the aim of a game is to be fun.
great game, love it with all my heart, the lost adventurer achievement can go blow its brains out in an alleyway.

If anything, Enter the Gungeon is more of a cover shooter rather than an actual bullet hell.
